title: 113_hr2250
content: The "Spending Reduction Act" requires agency reports on reducing duplication, achieving savings, and enhancing revenue. The "Spending Reduction Act" mandates executive agencies to report on implementing recommendations from specific Government Accountability Office reports to Congress. The "Spending Reduction Act" requires executive agencies to report on their agreement or disagreement with Government Accountability Office recommendations and provide their own recommendations for actions to be taken. The Comptroller General evaluates the agency's recommendations for consistency with the GAO reports. The "Spending Reduction Act" mandates executive agencies to respond to Government Accountability Office recommendations, propose legislative changes, assess cost impacts, and provide additional relevant information as deemed necessary by the agency head. SEC. 3. IMPLEMENTATION. Implementation of recommendations to eliminate, consolidate, streamline, or coordinate government programs and agencies with duplicative missions must begin within 150 days of the Act's enactment. Congressional disapproval can prevent an executive agency from carrying out these recommendations if a joint resolution is enacted within a 45-day period. The implementation of recommendations to eliminate, consolidate, streamline, or coordinate government programs and agencies with duplicative missions must start within 150 days of the Act's enactment. Congressional disapproval can halt these recommendations if a joint resolution is passed within a 45-day period or by the adjournment of Congress sine die for the session during which the report is submitted. Congress must consider executive agency reports according to Section 4 of the Act. The term "joint resolution" refers to a resolution introduced within a 10-day period after an executive agency submits a report to Congress. It must not have a preamble, must disapprove the agency's recommendations, and have a specific title. The joint resolution must be introduced within 10 days after an executive agency submits a report to Congress. It should not have a preamble, must disapprove the agency's recommendations, and have a specific title. If the resolution is not reported by the committee within 20 days, it will be discharged and placed on the House calendar. The joint resolution must be introduced within 10 days after an executive agency submits a report to Congress. If the resolution is not reported by the committee within 20 days, it will be discharged and placed on the House calendar for consideration. After the committee reports or is discharged, any Member can move to proceed with the resolution's consideration. The motion to proceed with the resolution is highly privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or postponement. Debate on the resolution is limited to 2 days. If the motion is agreed to, the respective House will immediately proceed to consider the resolution without interruption. The motion to proceed with the resolution is highly privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or postponement. Debate on the resolution is limited to 2 days. Appeals in connection shall be limited to 2 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the resolution. A motion to further limit debate is in order and not debatable. Postponement, consideration of other business, or recommitting the resolution is not allowed. A motion to reconsider the vote is also not in order. Following the debate, a vote on final passage of the resolution shall occur. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on the rules of the Senate or House are allowed. The rules of the Senate or House of Representatives apply to resolution procedures without debate. If one House receives a resolution from the other House, it cannot be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. The receiving House's procedure remains the same as if no resolution was received. Upon receiving a resolution from the other House, the receiving House must proceed to a final vote on the resolution without debate. Once the resolution is disposed of, it cannot be considered again. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, applicable only to resolution procedures and supersedes other rules if inconsistent. The receiving House must vote on a resolution from the other House without debate. The resolution cannot be reconsidered once disposed of. Congress enacted this section as part of each House's rules, specifically for resolution procedures, overriding any conflicting rules. The constitutional right of each House to change its rules regarding procedure is acknowledged. In this Act, the term "executive agency" is defined as provided in section 133 of title 41, United States Code.
